content.raw:
Cool! How about allowing comments in the unevaluated global to be preserved, i.e. add this to `handle_set_globals` \(I tried but don’t have write access to your runmanager fork\).

```python
# Keep any comments from previous_value if there aren't any in new_value
if keep_comments and '#' not in new_value:
    new_value_ = previous_value.split('#')
    new_value_[0] = new_value
    new_value = ' # '.join([x.strip() for x in new_value_])
```

Can also be done with regex, e.g. `re.sub(r'^(.+?)(?#)', new_value, previous_value)` \(without space santitisation\) if you don't mind importing `re`.
content.html:
Cool! How about allowing comments in the unevaluated global to be preserved, i.e. add this to handle_set_globals (I tried but don’t have write access to your runmanager fork).

# Keep any comments from previous_value if there aren't any in new_value
if keep_comments and '#' not in new_value:
    new_value_ = previous_value.split('#')
    new_value_[0] = new_value
    new_value = ' # '.join([x.strip() for x in new_value_])

Can also be done with regex, e.g. re.sub(r'^(.+?)(?#)', new_value, previous_value) (without space santitisation) if you don't mind importing re.

content.raw: Regex or string splitting isn’t ideal because you might have a hash character in a string, ideally one would use python’s tokenizer to split on the first thing that parses as a comment. The globals differ does this to _remove_ comments, I’ll see if I can use it to _keep_ them instead.
content.html: Regex or string splitting isn’t ideal because you might have a hash character in a string, ideally one would use python’s tokenizer to split on the first thing that parses as a comment. The globals differ does this to remove comments, I’ll see if I can use it to keep them instead.

content.raw:
Looks good from testing I’ve done. Only issues I see are:

* **Globals with the same name in multiple active groups:** `set_global` modifies the one in the first group of the ‘Groups’ tab. Should it instead return an error?
* **String values and Python expressions:** Setting a string value is done by passing `{"x": "my string"}`, but you cannot mimic entering a Python expression like `linspace(0, 1, 2)`. We could conditionally `repr` based on whether the value is a string-type, but that would require using extra quotes for actual string values \(which I’m fine with\).
content.html:
Looks good from testing I’ve done. Only issues I see are:

  • Globals with the same name in multiple active groups: set_global modifies the one in the first group of the ‘Groups’ tab. Should it instead return an error?
  • String values and Python expressions: Setting a string value is done by passing {"x": "my string"}, but you cannot mimic entering a Python expression like linspace(0, 1, 2). We could conditionally repr based on whether the value is a string-type, but that would require using extra quotes for actual string values (which I’m fine with).

content.raw:
First one sounds like should raise an error, will fix.

Second one, I’m thinking of having a ‘raw’ mode or something similar to make this distinction. So far `get_globals` returns the globals after being `eval`'d, and `get_globals_full` returns them as unevaluated strings \(as well as other info\). I’m thinking of perhaps rather than making the different functions behave differently, of adding a keyword argument to the set and get methods for whether Python objects or expressions should be passed around.

So you’d say `set_globals({x: 'linspace(0,1,2)'}, raw=True)`or perhaps `as_expression=True`.

Preferable to guessing based on the dtype.
content.html:
First one sounds like should raise an error, will fix.

Second one, I’m thinking of having a ‘raw’ mode or something similar to make this distinction. So far get_globals returns the globals after being eval'd, and get_globals_full returns them as unevaluated strings (as well as other info). I’m thinking of perhaps rather than making the different functions behave differently, of adding a keyword argument to the set and get methods for whether Python objects or expressions should be passed around.

So you’d say set_globals({x: 'linspace(0,1,2)'}, raw=True)or perhaps as_expression=True.

Preferable to guessing based on the dtype.

content.raw:
Further testing revealed something strange: occasionally shots don't have an updated global when calling `engage` immediately after `set_global` \(the latter takes effect as confirmed by viewing the GUI\). This went away when I put a short \(50 ms\) delay between the final `set_globals` call and `engage`.

This PR has made [M-LOOP integration](https://bitbucket.org/rpanderson/analysislib-mloop) \(or any other automated optimisation\) very nice, enabling the following:

* Single iteration of the optimisation loop can compile sequences, which is useful for multi-shot cost evaluation.
* The optimisation parameters get updated in the GUI, and as such, are set to the optimum values following each optimisation.
content.html:
Further testing revealed something strange: occasionally shots don't have an updated global when calling engage immediately after set_global (the latter takes effect as confirmed by viewing the GUI). This went away when I put a short (50 ms) delay between the final set_globals call and engage.

This PR has made M-LOOP integration (or any other automated optimisation) very nice, enabling the following:

  • Single iteration of the optimisation loop can compile sequences, which is useful for multi-shot cost evaluation.
  • The optimisation parameters get updated in the GUI, and as such, are set to the optimum values following each optimisation.

content.raw:
Thanks for catching that! I’ll see what I can do to make the `set_globals()` call block for long enough that it is guaranteed subsequent calls to `get_globals()` or `engage()`have the new values taken into account.

I did discover \(and fix - commit just pushed\) a bug though, in which multiple globals changes were being triggered. The code wasn’t correctly suppressing the treatment of globals changing as interactive, and so the effect of `set_globals({'x': b})`on a global initially set to `a`was that the global would change from `a` to `b`, then back to `a`, then back to `b` again. Perhaps this was the cause of the issue - that calls to `engage()` were catching this buggy code whilst the global was temporarily back at `a`. In fact, that sounds likely. `set_globals()` is synchronous with respect to writing the new global values to disk, and `engage()`reads them from disk, so I suspect the issue you saw is now fixed. But I’ll stress test to be sure.
content.html:
Thanks for catching that! I’ll see what I can do to make the set_globals() call block for long enough that it is guaranteed subsequent calls to get_globals() or engage()have the new values taken into account.

I did discover (and fix - commit just pushed) a bug though, in which multiple globals changes were being triggered. The code wasn’t correctly suppressing the treatment of globals changing as interactive, and so the effect of set_globals({'x': b})on a global initially set to awas that the global would change from a to b, then back to a, then back to b again. Perhaps this was the cause of the issue - that calls to engage() were catching this buggy code whilst the global was temporarily back at a. In fact, that sounds likely. set_globals() is synchronous with respect to writing the new global values to disk, and engage()reads them from disk, so I suspect the issue you saw is now fixed. But I’ll stress test to be sure.

content.raw: This fix has resolved the issue for me; new values take effect for every subsequent `engage` call.
content.html: This fix has resolved the issue for me; new values take effect for every subsequent engage call.

content.raw: Also, fantastic to see this integrated into your MLOOP integration! At this point I will likely be able to use your MLOOP analysislib code verbatim, so that’s great.
content.html: Also, fantastic to see this integrated into your MLOOP integration! At this point I will likely be able to use your MLOOP analysislib code verbatim, so that’s great.

content.raw: Please give it a shot. As per the [README](https://bitbucket.org/rpanderson/analysislib-mloop/src/default/README.md#markdown-header-is-this-implementation-limited-to-m-loop), it’s not at all limited to M-LOOP \(despite the name\), and can be applied to other optimisation libraries or feed-forward.
content.html: Please give it a shot. As per the README, it’s not at all limited to M-LOOP (despite the name), and can be applied to other optimisation libraries or feed-forward.

content.raw: If anyone else wants to test this, would be good! Otherwise I will merge it on Monday May 20th and bump the minor version number for release. (It is being used at NIST in the meantime so we will likely see any obvious issues in the meantime).
